title: Communicative Competence |  Competence & Performance | Langue & and Parole | Comparison
description:
In this video, we explore the concept of communicative competence as introduced by linguist Dell Hymes, highlighting how it differs from other key linguistic concepts like competence, performance, langue, and parole. Communicative competence refers to a speaker's ability to use language effectively in a variety of social contexts, not just to produce grammatically correct sentences. We compare this to linguistic competence, a term coined by Noam Chomsky, which focuses on a speaker's internal knowledge of grammar. We also delve into performance, which is the actual use of language in real-life situations, and the distinction between langue (the abstract system of language) and parole (the actual spoken or written instances of language use). This video provides a clear, concise understanding of these concepts and their interrelationships.
